subject.name: Medicine
subject.description: Foundational clinical reasoning scenarios covering patient history, diagnostics, and treatment priorities.
subject.source: Generated test content for Supabase integration testing

testlets.title: Clinical Reasoning Set 1
testlets.intro_html: Answer each clinical question based on the patient presentation. Select the best single response.

images.alt_text: A physician using a stethoscope during a clinical examination.

questions.stem_html: A 58-year-old man with long-standing hypertension presents with acute onset chest pain radiating to the back. Blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg in the right arm and 140/90 mmHg in the left arm. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic study?
questions.explanation_html: A tearing chest pain with unequal blood pressures suggests an aortic dissection. CT angiography rapidly confirms the diagnosis and informs surgical management.

questions.stem_html: A 32-year-old woman presents with fever, dysuria, and flank pain. Urinalysis shows white blood cell casts. Which organism is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation_html: Escherichia coli is the most common cause of acute pyelonephritis, especially in young sexually active women.

questions.stem_html: A 70-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation presents with sudden onset right lower quadrant abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. Which vascular territory is most likely affected?
questions.explanation_html: Atrial fibrillation predisposes to emboli that commonly lodge in branches of the superior mesenteric artery, leading to ischemic colitis in the right colon.
